technical_features.source_sentence: The results showed that the surface area of MgSBC-0.1 synthesized increased by 5.57 times.
MgSBC-0.1 can effectively remove phosphate in the initial solution pH range of 3.00–7.00, with a fitted maximum phosphorus adsorption capacity of 379.52 mg·g⁻¹.
The material surface contained MgO, Mg(OH)₂, and CaO nanoparticles.
MgSBC-0.1 can effectively remove phosphate in the initial solution pH range of 3.00–7.00.
The adsorption conforms to the pseudo second-order kinetics model.

HCO₃⁻ and CO₃²⁻ had the greatest competitive effect on phosphate due to their competitive binding sites with phosphate. Ca²⁺ and Fe³⁺ ions were found to enhance the adsorption of phosphate by MgSBC-0.1.
The pore volume (cm³·g⁻¹) [...] MgSBC-0.1 had values of [...] 0.17.
The adsorption efficiency [...] decreased to 59.48% after the third cycle.
The adsorbed P mainly exists in the form of MgHPO₄ and CaHPO₄.
The material after grinding was named MgSP, which was calcined in a tube furnace under a helium atmosphere at 500°C for 2 h.
A 0.1 mol·L⁻¹ Mg(CH₃COO) solution was prepared.
Equilibrium was achieved in roughly 2 h.

qualitative_insights.main_objective: Develop magnesium-loaded sludge-based biochar (MgSBC-0.1) for efficient phosphate adsorption from wastewater and subsequent reuse as agricultural fertilizer
key_methodology_summary: Synthesis via Mg impregnation and pyrolysis (500°C under helium)
Characterization using SEM, BET, XRD, XPS, FTIR, TEM
Batch adsorption experiments (kinetics, isotherms, pH effects, competing ions)
Real wastewater testing with rural biogas slurry
primary_findings_conclusions: 5.57x increased surface area in MgSBC-0.1 vs SBC
87.38% phosphate removal in real biogas slurry at 4 g·L⁻¹ dosage
limitations_discussed_by_authors: Significant adsorption inhibition by CO₃²⁻/HCO₃⁻ anions
Limited research on desorption mechanisms mentioned in introduction
future_work_suggested_by_authors: Scale-up for practical wastewater treatment applications
novelty_significance_claim: First demonstration of Mg-modified sludge biochar for phosphate recovery
7.17x higher adsorption capacity vs unmodified biochar
Dual Mg/Ca precipitation mechanism from sludge components
Successful application in real biogas slurry treatment
key_tables_figures_present: Figures 1-4: SEM/TEM morphology, BET isotherms, XRD/XPS/FTIR characterization
Figures 5-8: Adsorption performance under varying conditions
Figures 9/S1-S5: Mechanism analysis and reusability data
